column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.DemoNERRE|NamedentityTags
#T_RL=webanno.custom.DemoRE|NamedentityRelations|BT_webanno.custom.DemoNERRE
#Text=Polycrystalline samples of ZrFe4Si2 were synthesized by
#Text=a standard arc-melting technique on a copper hearth.
#Text=At first
#Text=stoichiometric amounts of the constituent elements (at least
#Text=99.9% purity) were melted in an arc furnace under argon
#Text=atmosphere, followed by several flipping and remelting of
#Text=the resulting ingot to ensure homogeneity.
#Text=Then the as-cast
#Text=samples were annealed at 1150 ◦C under a static argon atmosphere for a week.
#Text=The phase purity of the annealed
#Text=samples was checked by powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD)
#Text=using Cu Kα radiation and a scanning electron micrograph
#Text=(SEM).
#Text=Energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) analysis was used to
#Text=check the stoichiometry of the samples.
#Text=SEM studies reveal
#Text=only a small amount (up to 2%) of eutectic phase Fe3Si in
#Text=our samples, enabling us to study the intrinsic properties of
#Text=ZrFe4Si2.
#Text=PXRD patterns confirm the tetragonal P42/mnm
#Text=structure type with lattice parameters a = 6.9916(5) Å and
#Text=c = 3.7551(5) Å, in good agreement with those reported in
#Text=the literature [10].
#Text=Polycrystalline samples of the substitution
#Text=series ZrFe4(Si1−xGex )2 were also synthesized following the
#Text=same procedure.
#Text=EDX analysis provides the Ge concentrations
#Text=in the obtained samples as x = 0.12 (0.1), 0.23 (0.2), 0.34
#Text=(0.3), and 0.46 (0.4), where the corresponding nominal Ge
#Text=concentrations used in the synthesis are given in the parentheses.
#Text=SEM studies revealed that these samples contain up to
#Text=5% of impurity phases mainly consisting of Fe3(Si1−xGex).
